<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 117, 379, 142]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 194, 332, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 170, 905, 187]]<|/det|>
0625/12  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 194, 905, 210]]<|/det|>
February/March 2020  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[814, 217, 905, 231]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 247, 507, 263]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 277, 437, 293]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 291, 539, 320]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 337, 227, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 353, 905, 522]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(10 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 549, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 565, 806, 613]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

massweight

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 268, 138, 286]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 268, 306, 286]]<|/det|>
1200 N backwards

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 295, 138, 313]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 390, 480, 409]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 562, 133, 580]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 562, 566, 580]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 588, 133, 607]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 616, 314, 634]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Diagram 1 shows a tube sealed at one end and partly immersed in mercury. The tube has a diameter \(d\). The top of the mercury in the tube is a height \(h\) above the mercury reservoir.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 331, 737, 351]]<|/det|>
Diagram 2 shows a similar arrangement with a tube that has a diameter \(2d\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[379, 361, 615, 565]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 577, 465, 596]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 606, 138, 624]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 606, 208, 624]]<|/det|>
\(x = 2h\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 633, 136, 651]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 633, 198, 651]]<|/det|>
\(x = h\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 661, 136, 680]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 660, 203, 682]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 694, 136, 714]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 694, 203, 714]]<|/det|>
x = \(\frac{h}{4}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 573, 796, 592]]<|/det|>
The graph shows how its temperature changes with time as it is heated constantly.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 603, 539, 622]]<|/det|>

<label>19</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
Rods of the same shape and size are inserted through corks into a tank of hot water. Each rod is covered with a layer of solid wax that has a low melting point. After a period of time, some wax melts.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[276, 128, 719, 312]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 327, 415, 344]]<|/det|>
On which rod will the wax melt first?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 355, 134, 373]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 355, 316, 373]]<|/det|>
all at the same time

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 381, 134, 400]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 381, 351, 400]]<|/det|>
good thermal conductor

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 408, 134, 426]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 408, 339, 426]]<|/det|>
bad thermal conductor

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 435, 134, 453]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 435, 388, 453]]<|/det|>
moderate thermal conductor

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 478, 104, 496]]<|/det|>
<label>20</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 478, 920, 512]]<|/det|>
A boy jumps into an indoor swimming pool. He notices that the water appears to get colder as he goes deeper underwater. This is due to convection.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 523, 348, 541]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 552, 134, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 552, 803, 570]]<|/det|>
Cold water is more dense than warm water so it sinks to the bottom of the pool.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 579, 134, 597]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 579, 803, 597]]<|/det|>
Warm water is more dense than cold water so it rises to the surface of the pool.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 605, 134, 624]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 605, 920, 638]]<|/det|>
The molecules in cold water have more kinetic energy than the molecules in warm water so they move to the bottom of the pool faster.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 644, 134, 662]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>
